areaSection: Denia occupies a strategic position on the Costa Blanca, jutting into the Mediterranean with distinctive geography that sets it apart from neighboring towns. Located in the Marina Alta region of Alicante province, this historic port town blends Mediterranean charm with modern infrastructure. The climate is exceptional year-round, with over 300 days of sunshine, mild winters averaging 12°C, and warm summers around 28°C. Denia's elevation and sea breezes create a naturally cooling effect compared to inland areas. The town sits equidistant from major cities—Valencia to the north and Alicante to the south—making it accessible without urban congestion. This strategic location has transformed Denia into one of Spain's most cosmopolitan coastal destinations, attracting international buyers seeking authentic Mediterranean living with modern conveniences.
lifestyleSection: Daily life in Denia revolves around an enviable blend of coastal leisure and practical amenities. The international expat community—particularly British, German, Dutch, and French residents—creates a welcoming, English-friendly environment. Local markets operate daily with fresh produce, seafood, and Mediterranean specialties. Dining ranges from authentic paella restaurants overlooking the marina to contemporary tapas bars. Five magnificent beaches within 5-10km offer sandy shores and dramatic rocky coves. Golf enthusiasts have three championship courses nearby. Healthcare is excellent with English-speaking doctors at Marina Salud Hospital and modern medical centers. Shopping is convenient with Mercadona, Carrefour, and Lidl supermarkets. The thriving restaurant scene, water sports culture, and vibrant marina make Denia a dynamic base for investors managing holiday lettings.

However, this remains 35% less expensive than comparable Costa Brava properties. Denia's property market has appreciated 7% annually—significantly outpacing broader Spanish market growth. The three-bedroom configuration appeals to family holiday-makers and corporate bookings, diversifying your tenant base. Capital appreciation combined with rental income creates a compelling dual-return investment thesis.

faqs.question: Могут ли иностранцы купить недвижимость в Испании?
faqs.answer: Yes, non-resident foreigners can purchase property in Spain without restrictions. No visa is required for property purchase. The process involves opening a Spanish tax ID (NIE), engaging a local notary, and registering with land registry. British, European, and international buyers regularly purchase Spanish property through straightforward legal processes.

faqs.question: What are the rental income expectations for this property?
faqs.answer: This 3-bedroom apartment typically generates €900 weekly through holiday rental platforms. At 70% occupancy (conservative estimate), annual gross rental income reaches approximately €32,760. After property management fees (10-15%), platform commissions, utilities, and maintenance, net yields typically range 5-7% annually. Strong summer demand and year-round occupancy potential make Denia properties particularly lucrative.

faqs.question: What are the property taxes and ongoing costs in Spain?
faqs.answer: Non-resident property owners pay approximately 1.1% annual property tax (IBI). Utility costs average €80-120 monthly. Property management fees for holiday rentals range 10-15% of rental income. Community fees may apply for apartment buildings. Mortgage interest is deductible for non-resident owners, and rental income is taxable at standard rates (approximately 19-45% depending on total income). Costs are substantially lower than many EU markets.

faqs.question: Is Costa Blanca a good place to buy property as an investment?
faqs.answer: Yes, Costa Blanca is an excellent investment location. Property appreciates 7% annually, rental demand is consistent year-round, and the region attracts international tourists and relocation interest. Denia specifically benefits from port access, international amenities, and a cosmopolitan expat community. Compared to other European coastal markets, Costa Blanca offers superior value with lower entry prices and strong cash-flow potential.

faqs.question: How close is this property to Alicante Airport?

faqs.question: What is the weather like in Denia year-round?
faqs.answer: Denia enjoys Mediterranean climate with over 300 days of annual sunshine. Winters average 12°C (mild, rarely freezing), springs reach 18-20°C with wildflowers, summers peak at 28°C (warm but moderated by sea breezes), and autumn offers 20-22°C comfort. This consistent pleasant weather supports year-round holiday rental demand and outdoor lifestyle appeal.

faqs.question: Can I get a mortgage in Spain as a foreign investor?
faqs.answer: Yes, Spanish banks offer mortgages to non-resident foreign investors, typically 70% loan-to-value maximum. Interest rates are competitive (2.5-4% range depending on terms). Requirements include proof of income, NIE tax ID, and bank references. Many investors work with English-speaking mortgage advisors familiar with international applications. Purchase financing is straightforward for established investors.

faqs.question: What makes Denia different from other Costa Blanca towns?

Unlike purely tourist destinations, Denia functions as a real community with year-round residency appeal, sustaining consistent holiday rental demand.
